INTRODUCTION

2.
Air pollution, including acid rain, remains the most serious environmental problem in the
PRC. Industrial production and power generation are the two main sources of air pollution. The
effects  of  air  pollution  on  people  include  various  types  of  respiratory  and  heart  diseases  that
primarily affect children, the elderly, and other disadvantaged groups, with the poor suffering the
most. Among the negative impacts of acid rain are deterioration of human health, reduction of
agricultural  and  forestry  production,  poor  water  quality,  destruction  of  biologically  important
ecosystems, and damage to cultural and historical structures. The Government has formulated
a  comprehensive  plan  to  overcome  environmental  degradation  and  urban  pollution  associated
with  the  acid  rain  problem.  The  plan  targets  the  urban  industry,  energy  production,  and
residential  sectors  that  currently  use  coal  as  the  dominant  energy  source  and  are  therefore
responsible for much of the air pollution. The deterioration of environmental quality due to acid
rain is particularly acute in the Yangtze River Valley within Anhui Province which is a poor inland
province  in  the  central  part  of  the  PRC.  Benefits  from  reduced  acid  rain  are  nonexcludable  in
character and will accrue to all people living in the project area.

Over  the  past  two  decades,  the  PRC  has  made  major  progress  in  moving  from  a
planned  system  to  a  market-based  economy.  As  with  other  aspects  of  economic  and  social
development,  there  have  been  substantial  changes  in  the  PRC’s  environmental  agenda.
Regulatory  and  institutional  capacities  have  been  strengthened,  policies  supporting  energy
efficiency  and  clean  energy  have  been  adopted,  and  increased  information  dissemination  has
improved environmental awareness. From 1990 to 2000, PRC’s gross domestic product (GDP)
grew by about 9.2 percent annually. One of the costs of the country’s rapid economic expansion
is a worsening of environmental quality, including increased levels of acid rain. According to the
State Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA), acid rain currently falls over 30 percent
of the nation’s territory or 2.87 million km2 (Map 2). The economy’s continued reliance on coal
suggests that efforts to mitigate acid deposition causing emissions should be intensified to cope
with the projected increase in the demand for energy.

It  is  estimated  that  the  PRC  generates  about  90  percent  of  all  SO2  emission  in  East

Acid Rain Control

9.
Within  Anhui,  the  Huai  River  and  Chao  Lake  have  received  national  attention  due  to
environmental concerns. The Huai River, Chao Lake, and a portion of the acid rain control zone
along  the  Yangtze  River  Valley  (in  Anhui)  are  part  of  the  national  environmental  protection
program  established  in  1998.  Due  to  its  subtropical  climate  and  geographic  diversity,  Anhui
province is ecologically rich. The province also has a long-standing and strong cultural heritage.
Motivated by those factors and serious environmental damage to the fragile ecosystems due to
heavy industrial pollution, the province has pioneered in taking various initiatives to clean up the
environment.8  The  province  also  developed  a  well-thought-out  acid  rain  control  plan.  In  1997,
the  State  Council  designated  five  prefectures  (Chaohu,  Tongling,  Wuhu,  Maanshan,  and
Xuanzhou)  as  the  acid  rain  control  zone  of  Anhui  Province.  The  zone  was  extended  to  cover
ecologically sensitive Huangshan in 1998 (Map 2). The State Council requires these prefectures
to remedy damage caused by acid rain.

10.
During  9FYP  period  (1996-2000),  Anhui’s  environment  objectives  were  to  (i) bring
environmental pollution under control, (ii) improve the quality of the environment in major cities,
(iii) reduce degradation of natural-ecological systems, and (iv) integrate environmental planning
with  economic  and  social  development  efforts.  To  achieve  these  objectives,  the  Government
strengthened  the  legal,  regulatory,  and  institutional  framework  for  effective  environmental
management.  The 10FYP (2001-2005) further promotes the objectives of sustainable economic
and  social  development,  while  targeting  environmental  quality  improvements.    In  the
environment  sector  the  emphasis  is  on    (i)  reducing  the  total  pollution  loads  to  achieve  the
designated  ambient  air  and  water  quality  standards,  (ii) continuing  environmental  quality
improvements in the cities, (iii) reversing the degradation of ecologically sensitive areas, and (iv)
controlling and reducing environmental and ecological damage caused by acid rain.

2. 

Environmental Legislation and Regulations

12.
In the PRC, most environmental protection policies are implemented at the subnational
level within the framework of national legislation, regulations, and standards.  The provincial and
municipal  governments,  through  their  respective  environment  protection  bureaus  (EPBs),  are
responsible  for  implementing  national  policies  and  are  authorized  to  act  in  the  absence  of
national  standards.  Where  warranted  by  local  conditions,  provincial  EPBs  may  impose  more
stringent  standards  than  those  required  by  the  national  Government.  In  general,  Anhui  has
adopted national standards for air, water, and solid waste management.

13. With assistance from ADB and other aid agencies, the Government has issued a series
of  laws  on  the  use  of  natural  resources  and  has  instituted  a  system  of  monitoring,  recording,
and reporting the discharge of pollutants.10 During the 1990s, the major laws on prevention and
control  of  air,  water,  and  solid  waste  pollution  were  all  updated.    The  Air  Pollution  Prevention
and Control Law was amended in 1995 and again in early 2000. The current law allows more
flexibility  in  meeting  air  quality  objectives,  and  has  more  definitive  provisions  for  enforcement.
Supported  by  the  2000  amendment  to  the  Air  Pollution  Prevention  and  Control  Law,  the
Government,  in  its  10FYP  will  enforce  a  cap  on  SO2  emission  levels.  The  cap  is  a  necessary
first step in applying MBIs for environmental management such as emission permit trading. With
respect to SO2 and acid rain control, the law emphasizes a number of measures for improving
coal  quality:  (i) new  high-sulfur  coal  mines  (1.5 percent  or  higher  sulfur)  must  install  coal
washing  facilities;  (ii) existing  high-sulfur  coal  mines  must  install  washing  equipment  within
designated time limits; (iii) coal with sulfur content over 3 percent will neither be produced nor
used; and (iv) in designated areas in important cities, highly polluting fuels, including high-sulfur
coal, are to be phased out.

Standards and Incentives

National  standards  have  been  developed  for  emissions  and  ambient  concentrations  of
15.
pollutants. Ambient standards have been established for (i) air quality (three grades designated
for natural resource protection, urban, and industrial areas); (ii) environmental quality of surface
water; (iii) environmental noise in urban areas; (iv) fisheries water quality; and (v) marine water
quality.  PRC standards are generally similar to international norms.  Emissions standards have
also been established for industrial waste gases (e.g., SO2, NOX, TSP, and carbon monoxide),
wastewater, and solid waste.  These standards are updated periodically in response to health,
technological,  and  legal  developments.  ADB  has  provided  assistance  for  formulating,  refining,
and improving environmental standards and enforcement policies.15

16.
Anhui  is  following  the  central  Government’s  environmental  management  framework,
adopting  both  command-and-control  and  incentive  methods  to  reach  its  environmental  goals.
Command-and-control approaches include mandatory environmental impact assessment (ElA),
land  use  management,  emission  controls  and  enforcement  at  enterprises  that  do  not  meet
national  standards,  emission  permits,  closure  of  small-scale  highly  polluting  industries,
centralized treatment of wastes, and total emissions control. Emission monitoring is conducted
mainly by enterprises, with periodic compliance monitoring performed by EPBs. Environmental
monitoring stations operated by EPBs conduct ambient air quality monitoring.

17.
Economic  incentive  approaches  include  the  pollution  levy  system,  tradable  permits,
taxes  on  polluting  inputs,  and  tax  rebates  administered  at  the  municipal  level.  Levies  have
traditionally been collected only for the pollutant that most exceeds the corresponding emission
standard; the levies need to be modified to reflect environmental costs through charges on the
total  amount  of  emissions.  The  levies  also  need  to  be  increased  to  make  them  more  of  an
incentive for industries to make the necessary investments to reduce pollution. The existing SO2
tax,  based  on  total  amount  of  emissions,  is  collected  in  designated  SO2  and  acid  rain  control
zones. Funds from pollution levies will continue to be rebated to enterprises for improving their
pollution control facilities.

Lessons Learned

29.
The  PRC  Country  Assistance  Program  Evaluation  conducted  in  1998  indicates  that
since  1991  ADB’s  strategic  objectives  for  the  energy,  environment,  industry  sectors,  and  their

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

45.
The Project is designed to reduce acid rain in Anhui, a relatively poor province with a per
capita GDP that is only 72 percent of the national average. The air quality in the Yangtze River
Valley has deteriorated to harmful levels. Without intervention, air quality will further deteriorate
and  acid  rain  frequency  will  increase,  with  serious  negative  implications  for  public  health  and
economic  development.  APG  is  implementing  an  acid  rain  control  plan  to  address  these
concerns.  APG  has  demonstrated  strong  sense  of  ownership  of  the  Project  by  identifying
subprojects  with  adequate  provision  for  local  currency  financing.  A  cause-effect  and  project
objective tree analysis is found in Appendix 4.

46.
The  Project  is  an  integral  part  of  the  provincial  acid  rain  control  strategy,  and  is
consistent  with  the  Government’s  strategy  to  clean  up  the  environment  by  improving  air  and
water  quality  in  the  acid  rain  control  zone  of  the  PRC.  It  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  strategy  to
support  measures  for  environmental  improvement  and  natural  resource  management  in  the
PRC. The Project, if approved, will be the eighth environmental improvement project supported
by  ADB  in  the  PRC  and  the  first  to  focus  on  acid  rain  control.  It  will  also  be  the  first
environmental  improvement  project  to  be  implemented  solely  in  secondary  cities  (Guichi,
Huangshan, Tongling, and Wuhu).

B.

Objective and Scope

47.
The main objective of the Project is to improve the ambient air quality and reduce acid
rain to improve the environment in the Yangtze River Valley in Anhui Province. The Project will
promote  CP,  reduce  waste,  improve  energy  efficiency,  improve  the  environment  in  ecological
sites,  and  support  institutional  strengthening  for  environmental  management  and  enterprise
governance.

48.
The Project has three main components: (i) six CP promotion subprojects undertaken by
industrial enterprises, (ii) three environmental improvement and acid rain damage rehabilitation
(EI-ARD)  subprojects  in  ecologically  protected  areas  (Huangshan  and  Jiuhua  mountains),  and
(iii)  one  institutional  strengthening  component  to  be  undertaken  by  provincial  and  local
environmental agencies and subproject enterprises. The subprojects will reduce SO2 and other
gases causing acid rain through the use of CP technology, improved energy efficiency, reduced
waste,  and  technology  advancements;  and  will  improve  environmental  management  and
rehabilitate acid rain damage.

2.

capacity utilization. Capacity utilization with the Project in years 1, 2, and 3 onward are 75, 85,
and 90 percent for Anhui Tongdu Copper Limited Company (ATC), Chizhou Non-Ferrous Metals
Group Company (CNM), and Wuhu Hengchang Copper Refinery Copmany (WHC); 60, 80, and

contingencies are 5 percent of capital costs for all the subprojects.

B.

Cleaner Production Subprojects

2.
Electrolytic  copper  prices  are  based  on  international  prices  as  quoted  on  the  London
Metal Exchange (LME). There is a small premium in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) due
to the country’s supply and demand situation. Copper prices are volatile and have ranged from
Y13,545 to Y15,247 per ton in 2001. Since 1997, copper prices have ranged from Y11,243 to
Y16,647 per ton. The price of the company’s copper raw materials also moves closely with the
LME.  The  projections  for  ATC  assume  a  selling  price  of  Y15,339  per  ton.  ATC  will  realize
incremental  production  efficiency  from  the  subproject  due  to  the  installation  of  top-blown
submerged  lance  smelting  and  a  rotary  anode  furnace.  The  equipment  will  also  give  the
company  more  capability  to  process  lower-grade  raw  materials.  In  addition,  ATC  will  realize
energy cost savings of 12 percent per ton.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS

1.
Economic analysis was carried out on an incremental basis in constant prices.  Economic
returns are calculated over a 20-year period corresponding to the economic life of the subproject
investments.  For  the  major  traded  inputs  and  outputs,  the  economic  resource  flows  were
estimated in border prices using the domestic currency as numeraire. Traded goods valued at the
border  price  level  were  revalued  to  the  domestic  price  level  through  the  shadow  exchange  rate
factor (SERF) of 1.11 equal to the inverse of the standard conversion factor (SCF) of 0.9 that has
been  used  in  other  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  projects  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China
(PRC).  For  nontraded  items,  the  resource  flows  were  estimated  from  financial  prices  using
conversion factors and shadow prices. The economic analysis was conducted in accordance with
ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects.

A.

Economic Costs

2.
Data  for  capital  costs  was  taken  from  the  financial  analysis  adjusted  using  relevant
conversion factors, expressed in constant prices. In calculating economic capital costs, all duties,
subsidies,  taxes,  and  resource  transfers  were  excluded.  Only  real  resource  claims  were
considered in calculating incremental working capital. The price of electricity was set equal to an
updated  estimate  of  the  long-run  marginal  cost  of  production,  generation,  and  distribution  of
electricity in the PRC.1  The economic price of water was calculated by adapting a local survey
measure of willingness to pay (WTP) for each cubic meter (m3) of water.  The economic price of
water was equated with an income-adjusted updated household WTP value (Y/m3) for the control
and cleanup of wastewater discharges in Hefei (capital of Anhui). The nontraded labor inputs are
adjusted by the SCFs of 0.8, 1.0, and 1.2 for skilled, semiskilled, and unskilled labor, respectively.
A  weighted  (by  number  of  staff)  average  conversion  factor  was  applied  to  the  wage  and  salary
levels in the financial model. This labor conversion factor averaged between 0.80 and 0.82. Major
raw material inputs were adjusted by conversion factors reflecting border price equivalent values
and shadow prices.

B.

Economic Benefits

The  incremental  economic  benefits  from  the  six  cleaner  production  (CP)  subproject
3.
investments  are  derived  from  the  increased  value  of  output  (reflecting  increased  value  of
consumption  to  society),  foreign  exchange  savings,  production  efficiencies  involving  energy
conservation, and the use of solid waste by-products as raw material inputs.  A key efficiency and
environmental improvement feature of most of the subprojects is mining the waste stream (solid
and liquid) for valuable raw material inputs.  This waste stream utilization results in value-added
economic  activity.  Because  the  main  plant  outputs  from  the  subproject  investments  are
incremental,  the  shadow  price  applied  was  based  on  the  financial  market  price  inclusive  of  the
domestic consumption tax less subsidies to the buyer. Electrolytic copper is an output in several
of the subproject investments. Since refined copper consumption exceeds production in the PRC,
the  economic  price  for  electrolytic  copper  was  calculated  as  the  border  price  equivalent  value
adjusted  by  the  SERF.2  Several  of  the  subproject  investments  are  expected  to  result  in  energy
savings that are equivalent to a given amount of tons per year of standard coal equivalent.  These
savings  were  monetized  by  applying  the  economic  value  of  coal  to  the  annual  standard  coal
equivalent  volumes  (in  tons)  expected  to  be  saved.    The  economic  price  of  coal  was  a  border
price  equivalent  value.    Economic  prices  for  the  solid  waste  by-product  materials  were
determined from local market prices adjusted by conversion factor reflecting their shadow prices.
